personalized_feedback:
Andrea —

I’m genuinely pleased by how you’ve adopted the DRIVER mindset. You moved quickly from an ad-hoc approach to a repeatable process: you consistently decomposed problems into drivers, stated assumptions explicitly, and built logic guardrails that prevent cascading errors. I noticed concrete strengths — your scenario breakdowns tied model inputs to business levers (price, volume, margin) in a way that made trade-offs visible, and you used AI to accelerate execution while keeping final judgment clearly yours. Those are exactly the shifts that turn “monkey mind” work into systematic financial thinking.

For next steps, focus two practical improvements that will make your work more actionable for business leaders. First, tighten communication: accompany models with a one-page executive memo that states the key assumptions, the top three drivers that move the outcome, and the recommended decision rule (e.g., “invest if NPV > X under base and best-case”). Second, strengthen the remaining technical touchpoint you’ve been developing — run and present a sensitivity matrix (tornado chart + break-even points) that links small input changes to financial outcomes. In business settings, these two artifacts (concise memo + sensitivity matrix) turn analysis into decision-ready insight for CFOs and product leaders.

Keep thinking of this as a journey. The habits you’re building — decomposing problems, applying logic guardrails, and translating outputs into decisions — are career multipliers in finance. Continue iterating: each model you make is practice in clear thinking that will pay off on real investment committees and strategic reviews. If you want, bring your next model to office hours and we’ll work through the memo and sensitivity layout together.

Warmly,
Professor Zhang
